review.title: On the practically interesting instances of MAXCUT
review.abstract: The complexity of a computational problem is traditionally quantified based on the hardness of its worst case. This approach has many advantages and has led to a deep and beautiful theory. However, from the practical perspective, this leaves much to be desired. In application areas, practically interesting instances very often occupy just a tiny part of an algorithm's space of instances, and the vast majority of instances are simply irrelevant. Addressing these issues is a major challenge for theoretical computer science which may make theory more relevant to the practice of computer science.

metadata.title: On the practically interesting instances of MAXCUT

sections.text: Below [BL] we apply this perspective to MAXCUT, which is considered a cluster problem. We use a variety of techniques to study practically interesting cases of this problem. In particular, we show how to resolve differentiated, metric, expanding, and dense cases of MAXCUT in polynomial time under mild assumptions of stability. In particular, (1 +) stability (which is optimal) is sufficient for metric and dense MAXCUT. We also show how to resolve polynomial-stable cases of MAXCUT, greatly improving the best result known to date.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The primary criterion used in computational complexity to evaluate algorithms is therefore very specific. Although no efficient algorithm can solve all of its instances, this approach is often overly pessimistic in practice, and a more realistic (but blurred) criterion would be to say that a problem is feasible if there is an efficient algorithm that correctly solves all of its practically interesting instances. The difference can be very significant, as the vast majority of instances are completely irrelevant for practical purposes. An important case is where clusters occur where one seeks a meaningful partition of a given dataset. Almost every formal manifestation of the clustering problem is NP-Hard, but a clustering instance is of practical interest if the data can actually be partitioned in a meaningful way.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and open problems
sections.text: Our results, together with work from [AB, ABS, BL, DLS, BL2], show that in many cases practically interesting cases of hard problems are mathematically feasible. Much remains to be done towards a new paradigm of analyzing the complexity of computational problems of practical importance. Even if we limit our attention to MAXCUT, many problems remain open. Here are some of the more significant challenges: • Following [BL] we remember the (admittedly bold) assumption that there is a constant γ > 1 in polynomial time, s.t. - stable instances can be solved. • It is interesting to look for the best possible dependence on γ from α in theorem 1.2. We are fairly sure that further improvements are possible. • With reference to the conclusion 2.6, can you find a practically efficient algorithm for, for example, 2-spatially stable metric instances?
